Dear RICHARD WATKINS:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code License recommendation
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12325
Section • (1) An agency shall recommend to the department the
Description appropriate licensing action consistent with facts contained
in the foster home evaluation and any special evaluations.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency completed a poor assessment on their reopen narrative
for a provider. It is unclear if the file was reviewed or if they made
any sort of assessment of the current compliance since the
previous closure was due to an administrative close in response to
the previous agency’s recommendation of revocation. The agency
failed to indicate that there was a change in the applicant’s home
dynamics since the closure so there was no central office
Consultant review to address the previous disciplinary action unit
(DAU) file.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Licensing Supervisor was interviewed via video conferencing on
9/12/2024. She reported being the current supervisor of Licensing
Worker who completed the license re-opening of Foster Parent;
however, that occurred prior to Licensing Supervisor being
assigned. Licensing Supervisor reported she met Foster Parent a
couple of times and Foster Parent previously had placement of
two teens through the agency, but she is now homeless and in in
the middle of a special evaluation. Licensing Supervisor reported
her understanding is that DAU Manager referred Foster Parent to
New Light Child & Family Institute for licensing. Licensing
Supervisor states she typically reviews an applicant’s prior
licensing history before opening a license but did not know if the
supervisor assigned at the time, Program Manager, or Licensing
Worker reviewed Foster Parent’s file prior to re-opening Foster
Parent’s license.
Licensing Worker was interviewed via video conferencing on
9/12/2024. She stated Foster Parent talks to DAU Manager a lot
and DAU Manager referred Foster Parent to New Light Child &
Family Institute to have her license re-opened. Licensing Worker
stated she spoke to DAU Manager who told Licensing Worker to
open Foster Parent’s license. Licensing Worker stated this
conversation took place sometime in April and DAU Manager told
Licensing Worker there had been no findings in regard to previous
2

licensing investigations against Foster Parent and there was no
problem re-opening Foster Parent’s license following her prior
administrative closure. Licensing Worker stated she reviewed
Foster Parent’s previous licensing file and spoke to Foster Parent
who was “very honest.” Foster Parent sent Licensing Worker her
prior complaint investigations in which she was found in
compliance. Licensing Worker stated she would provide email
exchanges with DAU Manager in which DAU Manager supported
re-opening Foster Parent’s license; however, she was unable to
locate the emails. She also stated she had text messages from
DAU Manager supporting the re-opening and specifying Foster
Parent should only have one placement at a time; however, she
no longer had these text messages.
Licensing Worker stated this is the first license she re-opened
within a year of closure and that she did not know to document her
review of the licensing history in the re-opening narrative. She
stated she did not indicate this as a “change” when re-opening the
license because, even though Foster Parent had moved to a new
address, Licensing Worker couldn’t change the address in the
electronic file until the license was re-opened.
Licensing Worker reported Licensing Supervisor is currently
conducting two special evaluations on Foster Parent based on the
behavior of the youths placed in her home. Licensing Worker
stated Foster Parent moved to an unknown location because she
felt unsafe after one of her foster children perpetrated domestic
violence.
Program Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
9/19/2024. She reported having been the licensing supervisor at
the time Foster Parent’s license was re-opened. Program
Manager stated she received an email from Licensing Worker
earlier this year stating Foster Parent had contacted her and
wanted to re-open her license to take placement of teens after
which an orientation was scheduled. Licensing Worker then
emailed Program Manager there had been a revocation
recommendation made by Foster Parent’s prior licensing agency,
so the orientation was cancelled. Program Manager spoke to
Licensing Worker in person and Licensing Worker reported she
spoke to DAU Manager who said Foster Parent’s license was
closed administratively. Licensing Worker told Program Manager
she had an email from DAU Manager supporting the re-opening of
Foster Parent’s license.
3

Program Manager stated Licensing Worker reviewed Foster
Parent’s prior licensing history in her electronic file; however, this
was not documented in the re-open narrative.
Program Manager stated the re-open was recommended
indicating there had been no changes since the license closed,
despite Foster Parent having moved as well as there being an
agency change. Program Manager stated she believed a central
office consultant reviewed all re-open recommendations
regardless if it was indicated there had been a change.
DAU Manager was interviewed via video conferencing on
9/23/2024. She reported a revocation recommendation was
recommended for Foster Parent’s license late last year. DAU
Manager stated there were significant concerns documented in
that agency’s report; however, Foster Parent moved during the
disciplinary action process. Historically, if a foster parent moves
during the disciplinary process, the license is closed
administratively as foster home licenses are issued to a specific
person at a specific address; therefore, when a foster parent
moves to a different address, the license is invalidated eliminating
the need to continue the disciplinary action process. DAU
Manager stated Foster Parent has taken the administrative
closure as confirmation DAU Manager did not believe the
revocation recommendation was warranted; however, that is not
the case. DAU Manager stated she did speak with Licensing
Worker about Foster Parent in regard to Foster Parent’s licensing
still being open in the electronic system, preventing Licensing
Worker from submitted a re-open recommendation. DAU Manager
stated she did not offer an opinion to Licensing Worker about
recommending re-opening Foster Parent’s license. DAU Manager
reported she believed if any agency decided to recommend Foster
Parent for re-opening, even after reviewing her file, a central office
consultant would review the recommendation and deny the re-
opening of the license.
DAU Manager stated she believed Licensing Worker might be
confusing two families as DAU Manager did contact her about a
different foster family asking Licensing Worker to take a look at
the family’s record as a potential transfer. DAU Manager stated
Licensing Worker did and ultimately decided to not accept a
transfer for that family. DAU Manager stated she had record of
these emails but did not have any emails in which she discussed
anything related to an opinion regarding the re-opening of Foster
Parent’s license.
4

DOCUMENT REVIEW
The following documents were reviewed in Foster Parents’s
electronic record
- 9/24/2020 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw in which a violation
of Foster Parent’s care of children based on her physical,
mental, and emotional health.
- 5/13/2021 Special Evaluation Report completed by Catholic
Social Services of Washtenaw in which thirteen rule
violations were established resulting in a revocation
recommendation.
- 4/28/2022 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Methodist Children’s Home Society in which violations of
licensing rules related to Foster Parent’s ability to
understand how to care for children and not having the
ability to provide appropriate care of a child with behavioral
needs were established. That agency recommended a
Corrective Action Plan, and that Foster Parent no longer
care for children with severe behavioral needs or with DOC
levels.
- 8/31/2022 Disciplinary Action – Administrative Closure
- 1/17/2023 Special Evaluation Report completed by Forever
Families recommending a corrective action plan due to
Foster Parent not informing the agency she is homeless.
- 10/17/2023 Special Evaluation Report completed by
Forever Families recommending revocation of Foster
Parent’s License due to Foster Parent being found in
violation of nine licensing rules. The recommendation was
based on Foster Parent’s lack of understanding of how to
care for children, putting her own needs first, lacking
empathy, utilizing control and fear over youths, as well as
Foster Parent’s history of using manipulation of children
and professionals and agency/child shopping in an attempt
to hide her history and manipulate agencies into issuing her
a license.
- 2/14/2024 Disciplinary Action – Administrative Closure
letter from DAU Manager stating Foster Parent’s license
was being closed despite Forever Families recommending
revocation due to Foster Parent moving rendering her
license invalid.
- 6/10/2024 re-open indicating no change required for
reopen.
5

- 6/10/2024 re-open recommending Foster Parent be
reopened for the care of 4 males ages 11-17 with no
placement restrictions.
- 6/10/2024 Reopen narrative completed by Licensing
Worker which in part indicates Licensing Worker has no
doubt that Foster Parent’s heart is in the right place, and
she has the resources to foster again. Neither an
assessment of Foster Parent’s history nor any indication
Foster Parent’s history was reviewed is documented.
DCWL Technical Assistance Manual indicating a re-open
request must be submitted “with changes” if there is a change
of address. Additionally, the manual states if the agency
completing the reopen is not the original certifying agency the
narrative must include and make assessment regarding the
review of the applicant’s history.
Emails from Licensing Worker:
- 9/12/2024 forwarded email from DAU Manager to
Licensing Worker indicating there is a technical issue
with closing Foster Parent’s previous license
- 9/24/2024 email stating she was texting DAU Manager
while DAU Manager was on vacation in April during
which DAU Manager mentioned she was okay with
Foster Parent being opened and only one placement
would be appropriate. Licensing Worker wrote she did
not have the text messages
Email from DAU Manager:
- 9/24/2024 email stating she remembers speaking with
Licensing Worker while on vacation, but the conversation
was very short and related to the technical issues with
closing Foster Parent’s previous license.
Analysis The agency is found in violation as the recommendation to re-
open Foster Parent’s license was not consistent with the facts
located within Foster Parent’s licensing history. Foster Parent has
been previously licensed through three different agencies two of
which recommended revocation of Foster Parent’s license and
one of which recommended Foster Parent no longer provide care
for youths with severe behavioral needs. Foster Parent’s license
has been administratively closed twice and has been investigated
two additional times due to moving and not telling her assigned
agency and/or being homeless. It is documented Foster Parent
has a history of moving in order to have her license
administratively closed as opposed to being revoked based on
violations related to the care of youths. Additionally, once her
6

license is administratively closed, she approaches a different
agency to open/re-open her license in an attempt to hide her
history.
Despite all of these facts, New Light Child & Family Institute
recommended the re-opening of Foster Parent’s license for 4
youths, with no restrictions.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
